reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s opening, analogy-based move meant to block the inference from “no easy eutopia” to near-zero expected value. That move is part of the framing but not the essay’s main argumentative load (which later leans on convergence, trade/compromise, threats, institutions), so centrality is moderate. The objection is reasonably strong: flight/evolution involve tight, shared, low-noise feedback and stable objectives, whereas the essay itself stresses contested, high-dimensional value and weak/heterogeneous feedback—conditions where proxy optimization and Goodhart-like failures are common, so the analogy is at best weak evidence. However, it doesn’t fully refute the essay’s broader optimism, since the essay already acknowledges many of these difficulties and later provides more concrete mechanisms; at most it undercuts the initial intuitive support and shifts burden to later sections. The critique is largely correct and clearly stated, with little extraneous material and a single focused line of attack.
title: Lack of dense feedback signals makes eutopia unlike flight optimization
